channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: What Mike Tyson and the Bond Market Can Teach Trump on Debt
item.description: Treasury buyers will be the ultimate arbiters on whether MAGA math adds up.
item.dc:creator: Tom Orlik

item.title: Singapore Inflation Seen to Quicken as Conflict Spurs Oil Prices
item.description: Singapore’s key inflation gauge slowed in May though it will likely accelerate in the coming months as the attack on Iran spurs global crude costs higher.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li

item.title: Japan Approves Plan to Cut Super-Long Bond Sales by $22 Bln
item.description: Japan will reduce its issuance of super-long bonds starting in July, taking a step to calm a bond market rattled by recent surges in yields.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Euro Zone’s Private Sector Near Stagnation on Uncertainty
item.description: The euro area’s private sector barely grew in June, remaining in limbo as erratic US trade policy and geopolitical conflicts leave companies in the dark on what’s next.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: UK Private Sector Grows at Fastest Pace Since Trump Tariffs Hit
item.description: The UK private sector expanded at a marginally faster pace in June, helping ease worries of an economic contraction in the second quarter, according to a closely watched survey.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: Four Scenarios Facing a Trump-Rattled World Economy
item.description: With the US attack on Iran, Trump has injected new geopolitical risks into an already fragile global economy
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

media:content.media:description: US Vice President JD Vance, from left, US President Donald Trump, Marco Rubio, US secretary of state, and Pete Hegseth, US secretary of defense, during an address to the nation in the East Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 21, 2025. Trump said the US military struck three sites in Iran on Saturday, marking the first American involvement in direct attacks against Iranian nuclear assets in its conflict with Israel. Photographer: Carlos Barria/Reuters

item.title: German Private Sector Grows With Industry Closer to Turnaround
item.description: Germany’s private-sector economy returned to growth this month, buoyed by the best manufacturing performance since 2022 that shows the sector’s prospects may finally be improving.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: Japan’s LDP Suffers Bruising Loss in Tokyo Before National Vote
item.description: Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party suffered its worst-ever result in a Tokyo metropolitan election, losing its spot as the biggest political force on the assembly less than a month before voters deliver a verdict on Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s premiership in a national vote.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, Japan's prime minister, at the Nikkei Future of Asia forum in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. The forum will continue through May 30.

item.title: UK’s Efforts to Create Municipal Bond Market Fall Flat
item.description: A UK agency set up to kick-start the country’s municipal bond scene has closed to new business, abandoning a decade-long push to emulate vibrant markets in the US and Europe.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie

item.title: India Growth Firm as Export Orders Soar in June
item.description: India’s economic activity picked up in June, driven by a surge in new export orders that boosted the manufacturing sector, according to a flash survey by HSBC Holdings Plc.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy, Prateek Mazumdar

item.title: Oil Market Get Fresh Injection of Uncertainty After US Strikes Iran
item.description: US strikes on Iran over the weekend have added to risks for global oil supply, which has so far been unaffected by some of the most extreme military actions in the Middle East in years.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Sarah Chen, Dan Murtaugh, Nicholas Lua

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images Photographer: Brandon Bell/Getty Images North America

item.title: China Land Sales Income Hits Decade Low, Widening Budget Deficit
item.description: China’s revenue from selling land plunged to the lowest in a decade, contributing to the widening of budget deficit as the government ramped up spending in support of the economy.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang

item.title: Japan PMI Pickup Points to Front-loading Ahead of US Tariff Jump
item.description: Japan’s manufacturing activity expanded for the first time in more than a year in June in a likely sign of front-loading of output ahead of a scheduled increase in US tariffs next month.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Korea’s Early Exports to US Jump Ahead of Tariff Deadline
item.description: South Korea’s early trade data for June showed the biggest rise in exports to the US so far this year, indicating that manufacturers may have rushed shipments ahead of a July deadline that will see broad tariffs rates more than double.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: IMF’s Georgieva Warns of Broader Risks From US Strikes on Iran
item.description: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that the US strikes on Iran could potentially have broader impacts beyond energy channels, as global uncertainty escalates.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn, Yuko Takeo

media:content.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva in Tokyo on June 23.

item.title: Rupee’s Fall Near Key Level to Test RBI’s Tolerance for Swings
item.description: The Indian rupee’s decline against the dollar is pushing it closer to a critical threshold, raising expectations that the nation’s central bank may step in to stabilize the currency as global tensions mount.
item.dc:creator: Pratigya Vajpayee, Bhaskar Dutta

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says Employment, Inflation Risks Roughly in Balance
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said she sees the central bank’s monetary policy stance as “in a good place” currently, with risks to its US employment and price stability mandates as roughly equal.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres, Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, during the National Association of Business Economics (NABE) economic policy conference in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Feb. 16, 2024. The theme of this year's annual meeting is Navigating Geopolitical Turbulence and Domestic Uncertainty. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Mild US Inflation Is Backdrop for Fed’s Powell on the Hill
item.description: US inflation probably inched higher in May, offering scant evidence of extensive tariff-related repercussions that the Federal Reserve expects to become more apparent later in the year.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 18, 2025. Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and continued to pencil in two rate cuts in 2025, saying uncertainty over the economic outlook was still high but had diminished.

item.title: Euro-Area Economy Needs More ECB Stimulus, Centeno Tells Stampa
item.description: The European Central Bank needs to provide the euro-area economy with “further stimulus,” Governing Council member Mario Centeno told Italy’s La Stampa.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss, Daniele Lepido

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB), in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. After cutting interest rates eight times in a year to bring inflation to around their 2% target, ECB policymakers are signaling they’re well positioned to tackle any sudden shifts in the economic backdrop.

item.title: Malaysia Says US Agrees to Finalize Trade Talks Before Deadline
item.description: Malaysia and the US have agreed to finalize trade negotiations before the tariff reprieve expires, the Malaysia’s Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry said.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

item.title: US Strikes on Iran Come at Fragile Moment for the Global Economy
item.description: US strikes on Iran’s three main nuclear facilities come at a fragile moment for the global economy, and the outlook now hinges on how forcefully the Islamic Republic retaliates.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan, Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ATTA KENARE/AFP

item.title: Farage’s Rise Calls Bank of England Independence Into Question
item.description: In the nearly three decades since Gordon Brown handed control of interest rates to the Bank of England, the move has been broadly viewed as a success in helping to keep inflation under control. Now that consensus appears to be breaking down.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Nigel Farage Photographer: Jason C. Andrew/Bloomberg

item.title: UK to Invest £275 Million to Train Skilled British Workers
item.description: The UK will invest £275 million ($371 million) to grow the country’s skilled workforce as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to accelerate economic growth and reduce reliance on foreign labor.
item.dc:creator: Tofe Ayeni

media:content.media:description: Workers on the HS2 High-Speed railway construction site at Old Oak Common in London, UK, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. Costs attached to the rail project, which was originally designed to link London to Manchester and Leeds, via Birmingham, had risen to as much as 98 billion ($128 billion) by 2020, up from an initial estimate of 37.5 billion for the entire network.
